3. Assume-Guarantee (A/G) Contracts¶

3.1. What is an A/G Contract?¶

An assume-guarantee (A/G) contract \(C\) is a triple \((V,A,G)\) where \(V\) is the set of variables, \(A\) is the set of behaviors which a component (or system) expects from its environment, and \(G\) is the set of behaviors that the component promises given that the environment provides behaviors within the assumption set. We say \(M\) is an implementation of \(C\) by writing \(M \models C\).

A contract is in saturated form if it satisfies \(\overline{A} \subseteq G\) where \(\overline{A}\) is the complement of \(A\). An unsaturated contract \(C'=(V,A,G)\) can always be saturated to the equivalent contract \(C=(V,A,G')\) where \(G'=G \cup \overline{A}\).

An A/G contract \(C = (V,A,G)\) is compatible if there exists an environment behavior over the set of variables \(V\), i.e., \(A \neq \emptyset\), consistent if there exists a behavior satisfying the (saturated) guarantees, i.e., \(G \neq \emptyset\), and feasible if there exists a behavior that satisfies both the assumptions and the guarantees, i.e., \(A \cap G \neq \emptyset\).

Via refinement, we can reason about different abstraction layers in system design. A contract \(C_2 = (V,A_2,G_2)\) refines \(C_1 = (V,A_1,G_1)\) if and only if (1) \(A_1 \subseteq A_2\) and (2) \(G_2 \subseteq G_1\). We denote this relationship as \(C_2 \preceq C_1\). Intuitively, if a contract \(C_2\) refines another contract \(C_1\), then \(C_2\) can replace \(C_1\). For further details we refer to the monograph [ContractMono].

3.2. A/G Contracts in PySTL¶

3.2.1. Creating an A/G Contract¶

Consider the component above. An STL contract \(C_1 = (V_1,A_1,G_1)\) where \(V_1 := \{ x, y \}\), \(A_1 := \mathbf{G}_{[0,3]}(x \geq 5)\), and \(G_1 := \mathbf{G}_{[1,4]}(y \geq 2)\) can be created as follows:

from pystl import *
import numpy as np

c1 = contract('c1')                   # Create a contract c1
c1.set_deter_uncontrolled_vars(['x']) # Set a deterministic uncontrolled variable
c1.set_controlled_vars(['y'])         # Set a controlled variable

c1.set_assume('(G[0,3] (x => 5))')    # Set assumptions of c1
c1.set_guaran('(G[1,3] (y => 2))')    # Set guarantees of c1
c1.checkSat()                         # Saturate c1
c1.printInfo()                        # Print information of c1

Using StSTL specifications, a contract \(C_1' = (V_1', A_1', G_1')\) where \(V_1' = U' \cup X_1'\), \(U_1' := \{ w_1, w_2 \}\), \(X_1' := \{ x, y \}\), \(A_1' := \mathbf{G}_{[0,3]}(5 \leq x)\), \(G_1' := \mathbf{G}_{[1,3]}(P\{ y-2w_1+3w_2 \leq 8 \} \geq 0.95)\), and \(\mathbf{w} = [w_1, w_2]^T \sim N([0,2]^T, [[1,0],[0,1]])\) can be created as follows:

c1_prime = contract('c1')                                      # Create a contract c1_prime
c1_prime.set_deter_uncontrolled_vars(['x'])                    # Set a deterministic uncontrolled variable
c1_prime.set_nondeter_uncontrolled_vars(['w1', 'w2'], \
      mean = np.array([0, 2]), cov = np.array([[1**2, 0], [0, 1**2]]))
                                                               # Set nondeterministic uncontrolled variables
c1_prime.set_controlled_vars(['y'])                            # Set a controlled variable
c1_prime.set_assume('(G[0,3] (5 <= x))')                       # Set assumptions of c1_prime
c1_prime.set_guaran('(G[1,3] (P[0.85] (y - 2w1 + 3w2 <= 8)))') # Set guarantees of c1_prime
c1_prime.printInfo()                                           # Print c1_prime

Any contract in PySTL can be saturated and its information can be printed. For example, \(C_1\) and \(C_1'\) can be saturated and their information can be printed as follows:

c1.checkSat()                         # Saturate c1
c1.printInfo()                        # Print c1

c1_prime.checkSat()                   # Saturate c1_prime
c1_prime.printInfo()                  # Print c1_prime

Please note that in PySTL, contracts are automatically saturated whenever necessary.

3.2.2. Checking Compatibility, Consistency, and Feasibility¶

We can check compatibility, consistency, and feasiblity of the contract \(C_1\). This includes when PySTL checks for compatibility, consistency, and feasiblity.

c1.checkCompat(print_sol=True)        # Check compatibility of c1
c1.checkConsis(print_sol=True)        # Check consistency of c1
c1.checkFeas(print_sol=True)          # Check feasiblity of c1

3.2.3. Refinement¶

Let’s create two more contracts \(C_2\) and \(C_3\) and check their compatibility, consistency, and feasiblity:

c2 = contract('c2')                   # Create a contract c2
c2.set_deter_uncontrolled_vars(['x']) # Set a deterministic uncontrolled variable
c2.set_controlled_vars(['y'])         # Set a controlled variable

c2.set_assume('(F[0,3] (x => 5))')    # Set assumptions of c2
c2.set_guaran('(G[0,3] (y => 3))')    # Set guarantees of c2
c2.checkSat()                         # Saturate c2
c2.printInfo()                        # Print information of c2

c3 = contract('c3')                   # Create a contract c3
c3.set_deter_uncontrolled_vars(['x']) # Set a deterministic uncontrolled variable
c3.set_controlled_vars(['y'])         # Set a controlled variable

c3.set_assume('(F[0,3] (x => 5))')    # Set assumptions of c3
c3.set_guaran('(F[1,3] (y => 3))')    # Set guarantees of c3
c3.checkSat()                         # Saturate c3
c3.printInfo()                        # Print information of c3

We can check whether \(C_2\) and \(C_3\) refines \(C_1\) or not:

c1.checkRefine(c2)                   # Check whether c2 refines c1
c1.checkRefine(c3)                   # Check whether c3 refines c1

Similarly, it is also possible to check refinement between probabilistic contracts. For an example with STL contracts refer to test_contracts.py and test_contracts_stl.py. For an example with StSTL contracts refer to test_contracts_ststl.py.

3.3. A/G Contracts Operations¶

A/G contracts \(C_1 = (V_1, A_1, G_1)\) and \(C_2 = (V_2, A_2, G_2)\) can be combined using contract operations: conjunction (\(\wedge\)) and composition (\(\otimes\)). A combined contract using these contract operations can be computed as follows:

\[\begin{split}C_1 \wedge C_2 = & \; (V_1 \cup V_2, A_1 \cup A_2, G_1 \cap G_2) \\ C_1 \otimes C_2 = & \; (V_1 \cup V_2, (A_1 \cap A_2) \cup \overline{(G_1 \cap G_2)}, G_1 \cap G_2)\end{split}\]

An A/G contract \(C = (V, A, G)\) can also be decomposed via the quotient operation. Given a contract \(C_2 = (V_2, A_2, G_2)\) the quotient contract \(C/C_2\), has the following properties:

\[\begin{split}& C / C_2 \otimes C_2 \preceq C \\ & \forall C_1, C_1 \otimes C_2 \preceq C \leftrightarrow C_1 \preceq C / C_2\end{split}\]

The quotient can be computed as follows [Passerone19]:

\[C / C_2 = (V \cup V_2, A \cap G_2, (G \cap A_2) \cup \overline{(A \cap G_2)})\]

3.4. A/G Contracts Operations in PySTL¶

3.4.1. Combining Contracts¶

Assume that we have contracts \(C_1\) and \(C_2\), we can combine them by using conjunction and composition.

c12_conj = conjunction(c1, c2)          # Conjunction of c1 and c2
c12_conj.printInfo()                    # Print c12_conj

c12_comp = composition(c1, c2)          # Composition of c1 and c2
c12_comp.printInfo()                    # Print c12_comp

For an example where contracts are combined, refer to test_contracts_combine.py.

3.4.2. Decomposing Contracts¶

Assume that we have contracts \(C\) and \(C_2\). We can split \(C\) into \(C_2\) and \(C / C_2\) by using quotient such that \((C / C_2) \otimes C_2 \preceq C\).

c2_quo = quotient(c, c2)                # Quotient c/c2
c2_quo.printInfo()                      # Print c2_quo

c2_comp = composition(c2_quo, c2)       # Composition of c2_quo and c2
c2_comp.printInfo()                     # Print c2_comp

c.checkRefine(c2_comp)                  # Check whether c2_comp refines c

For an example where contracts are split using quotient operation, refer to test_contracts_quotient.py.

We can also split \(C\) into \(C_2\) and \(C%C_2\) by using separation such that \(C \preceq (C/C_2) \cdot C_2\).

3.4.3. PySTL Contract Class and Its Operations¶

pystl.contracts.composition(c1, c2)¶

Returns the composition of two contracts

Parameters:
  • c1 (pystl.contracts.contract.contract) – A contract c1
  • c2 (pystl.contracts.contract.contract) – A contract c2
Returns:

A composed contract c1*c2
Return type:

pystl.contracts.contract.contract
pystl.contracts.conjunction(c1, c2)¶

Returns the conjunction of two contracts

Parameters:
  • c1 (pystl.contracts.contract.contract) – A contract c1
  • c2 (pystl.contracts.contract.contract) – A contract c2
Returns:

A conjoined contract c1^c2
Return type:

pystl.contracts.contract.contract
class pystl.contracts.contract(id='')¶

A contract class for defining a contract object.

Parameters:id (str) – An id of the contract
checkCompat(print_sol=False, verbose=True)¶

Checks compatibility of the contract.

checkConsis(print_sol=False, verbose=True)¶

Checks consistency of the contract

checkFeas(print_sol=False, verbose=True)¶

Checks feasibility of the contract

checkRefine(contract2refine, print_sol=False)¶

Checks whether the self contract refines the contract contract2refine

checkSat()¶

Saturates the contract.

set_assume(assumption)¶

Sets the assumption of the contract.

Parameters:assumption (str) – An STL or StSTL formula which characterizes the assumption set of the contract
set_controlled_vars(var_names, dtypes=None, bounds=None)¶

Adds controlled variables and their information to the contract

Parameters:
  • var_names (list) – A list of names for controlled variables
  • dtypes (list, optional) – A list of variable types for controlled variables, each entry can be either “BINARY”, “INTEGER”, or “CONTINUOUS”, defaults to “CONTINUOUS”, defaults to None
  • bounds (numpy.ndarray, optional) – An numpy array of lower and upper bounds for controlled variables, defaults to [-10^4,10^4] for “CONTINUOUS” and “INTEGER” variable and [0,1] for “BINARY”, defaults to None
set_deter_uncontrolled_vars(var_names, dtypes=None, bounds=None)¶

Adds deterministic uncontrolled variables and their information to the contract

Parameters:
  • var_names (list) – A list of names for uncontrolled variables
  • dtypes (list, optional) – A list of variable types for controlled variables, each entry can be either “BINARY”, “INTEGER”, or “CONTINUOUS”, defaults to None
  • bounds (numpy.ndarray, optional) – An numpy array of lower and upper bounds for controlled variables, defaults to [-10^4,10^4] for “CONTINUOUS” and “INTEGER” variable and [0,1] for “BINARY”, defaults to None
set_guaran(guarantee)¶

Sets the guarantee of the contract.

Parameters:guarantee (str) – An STL or StSTL formula which characterizes the guarantee set of the contract
set_nondeter_uncontrolled_vars(var_names, mean, cov, dtypes=None)¶

Adds uncontrolled variables and their information to the contract. We plan to add more distribution such as UNIFORM, TRUNCATED_GAUSSIAN, or even a distribution from DATA

Parameters:
  • var_names (list) – A list of names for uncontrolled variables
  • mean (numpy.ndarray) – A mean vector of uncontrolled variables
  • cov (numpy.ndarray) – A covariance matrix of uncontrolled variables
  • dtype (str, optional) – A distribution type for uncontrolled variables, can only be GAUSSIAN for now, defaults to None
